moves.1. e4 a6: An unusual opening designed, I assume, to confuse White.  As far as I can tell this is an absolute waste of a move except in so far as it prevents a Ruy Lopez opening and generally limits White's King's bishop.
moves.2. b3: White opts to direct play towards the King-side, looking for Bb2 to control the diagonal.
moves.2... Nc6 3. Nf3 e5 4. Bb2 Qf6: ? Early queen play while Black is undeveloped seems unwise.
moves.5. d4: The thought here was to force Black off the diagonal by pressure.
moves.5... Bd6: Saves the pawn, but at the cost of blockading the QP.
moves.6... Nxd4: An unexpected opening to the exchange from my (White's) point of view, and forces the issue uncomfortably.
moves.7. Nxd4 exd4 8. Qxd4: If 8. Bxd4, then the continuation ...Be5 9. c3 to protect the Rook is awkward at best.
moves.8... Qxd4 9. Bxd4 f6: White comes out with a far superior position and the attack, but very little to attack.  Pawn pressure may be in order.
moves.10. Nd2 Be5 11. Bxe5: A mistake, as it removes the bishop pressure too easily.  Better is 11. Nf3.
moves.11... fxe5 12. O-O d6 13. Nc4: The Knight has nowhere to play; again, Nf3 is better.
The fatal mistake.  I outright missed the 37. ... Nxg5 move in my eagerness to press the pawn attack.
moves.38... Nxe4+ 39. Kh4 g5+ 40. Kh3: 40. Kxh5 is a possibility, but ... Rh8 would cause all sorts of other problems.
moves.41... Rxf5: Resignation is highly in order; White does so.  A hugely misplayed game for me.  This game made me realize I need to work on pawn positions much more than I had thought.
